alert.note: Alert for Coconino; Yavapai (Arizona) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 6:10AM MST until March 16 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Flagstaff
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Arizona... Oak Creek near Sedona affecting Yavapai and Coconino Counties. .Heavy rain will fall on a deep primed snowpack leading to the melt increasing. Flows in rivers will increase quickly and reach critical levels. For Oak Creek...including Sedona...Minor to moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor to moderate flooding is currently forecast. * WHERE...Oak Creek near Sedona. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 5.0 feet, Multiple private low water crossings and bridges over Oak Creek above Sedona become impassable. At 7.0 feet, Likely to cause minor flooding downstream in page springs area near gage oaca3 4 to 6 hours later. At 13.0 feet, Stream reaches terrace near tlaquepaque bridge. Water reaches edge of several residential and commercial properties near tlaquepaque bridge. Low water crossings closed. At 14.0 feet, Flood stage. Several islands downstream in sedona evacuated. Minor flooding of access roads, buildings, and residences along oak creek. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:45 PM MST Tuesday /1:45 PM MDT Tuesday/ the stage was 4.7 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 13.2 feet late this evening. It will then fall and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.22 feet on 02/15/2019. - Visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for more information on flood safety. && Fld Observed Forecasts (6 am MST) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Oak Creek Sedona 14.0 4.7 Tue 12 pm MS 8.1 5.5 4.7 &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at: http://ahps2.wrh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=fgz The next statement will be issued this evening by 615 PM MST.
